repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
Font rendering and kerning are subpar in GUIs.

Solution:
Set default 'guifont' based on common CSS fonts mentioned at:
https://github.com/system-fonts/modern-font-stacks#monospace-code

fix #20356

comment_data.body: can move this to `reset()`, just after line 47. that should cover all the cases in this file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -53,6 +53,7 @@ describe('UI receives option updates', function()
 
   it('for defaults', function()
     local expected = reset()
+    expected.guifont = eval('&guifont')

comment_data.body: This isn't totally correct, can use `defaults.doc` to improve this. But CI is passing so I'll merge this PR and fix it later. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4719b944437b62407d36e718e64dfb0d316934d1/src/nvim/options.lua#L608-L610
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3344,7 +3340,7 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 <
 
 					*'guifont'* *'gfn'* *E235* *E596*
-'guifont' 'gfn'		string	(default "")
+'guifont' 'gfn'		string	(default "Source Code Pro, DejaVu Sans Mono, Courier New")

comment_regular_data.body: Will need to have more than just `if_false` / `if_true`, since there are more than 2 platforms.  Figuring out how to do that is part of the work here.
Do you think it would make sense to follow what `DFLT_EFM` did and use `macros` with the definition in `option_vars.h`?
I'm not sure what to do about the functional tests. Adding these to `Screen:new` would work, but it would have to use the same `#if` chain, which doesn't feel right/

> Adding these to `Screen:new` would work

Not sure what `Screen:new` has to do with it. In the test "expected" case(s), you can do something like this, to get the actual value from the `nvim` test session:

    guifont = n.eval('&guifont')

Thanks! (Also sorry I'm so late)

The `Screen:new` comment was just me being confused by `ext_linegrid` being handled separately
LGTM after last comment, then can move out of Draft ?
Will do. Any way I can fix the commit lints? I suppose force-pushing would work
yes, force-push. or i will fix the commit when merging
Oh right, the docs will change by the machine it runs on, I'll manually edit and push that

I think this may need to be reverted, at least for linux due to https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/3370
Not all linux distributions package these fonts. Even if I manually set a guifont I have installed, neovide throws an error about missing the default fonts. neovide may not be the only gui affected.
I think adding `monospace` to the Linux defaults should work, since `fontconfig` should resolve that to a system font if none of these fonts are installed.

it breakes neovide due to the new comma-separated list of fonts as default, so using

```
"SF Mono, Menlo, Monaco, Courier New"
```

our parser currently dont trim the splits so we face an invalid font family using a space as prefix.

eg. ` Menlo` or ` Monaco` etc.

we through an error if all families arent loaded due to this parsing problem.

@justinmk @yrahul3910 I can do a patch on neovide *nightly* to support the new neovim defaults,
but for people who uses *neovim nightly* with neovide *stable* in specific, will be impacted.

Sorry for the trouble, @falcucci! 

@justinmk I could PR the fixes above (remove leading/trailing whitespace, add `monospace` as a last-resort)

I have built a custom artifact just to test and this works great without breaking neovide on macOS at least.

```c
# define DFLT_GFN "Menlo,Monaco,Courier New"
```

SF Mono doesnt seem reliable and isnt listed in the default fonts supported by apple at least at their [support](https://support.apple.com/en-us/120414) page as I could check. All remaining ones are there.

and for linux and windows we probably would need to do the same, using only reliable fonts supported by the OS as default at least for now if we want to avoid affecting neovide *stable* users using nvim *nightly* until we release a new stable version at neovide.

> Sorry for the trouble, @falcucci!

it's just very unfortunate that the neovide parser wasn't resilient enough to accept this change on stable, so no need for sorry we will improve it on our side as well.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat: set reasonable per-platform 'guifont' defaults
